Award.AwardTitle: EMERGE - Establishing a Means for Effective Renewabale/Green Energy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project contributes to the study of science and engineering education by addressing the research question, "Do project-based learning instructional strategies integrated with sustainability content have an impact on student enrollment and retention in STEM college credit certificates and degrees?" Research-informed activities will focus on the development and pilot testing of several coordinated strategies: (1) providing secondary students with opportunities to earn industry certifications by incorporating a replicable Sustainable Engineering certificate within an Early College dual enrollment program; (2) increasing general science knowledge and interest in STEM by offering relevant sustainability courses to both scientist/technicians and non-science college majors; and (3) meeting workforce and societal needs by engaging students in learning sustainability content, embedded within multiple STEM degree and certificate programs.

Project objectives and outcomes include: (1) developing a new 18 credit hour/6 course Sustainable Engineering certificate containing specializations tied to industry certifications; (2) increasing enrollment in Sustainable Engineering courses; (3) increasing the number of students pursing the embedded Sustainable Engineering certificate as part of their degree program; and (4) increasing knowledge of scientists/technicians and non-scientists exposed to sustainable/renewable concepts. Outcomes will further support the development of replicable models for STEM student success, and will impact the training of the future science and technology workforce, increasing participation among underrepresented groups and those empowered by their knowledge about green technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Background & Purpose

Despite an ever-growing demand for "green jobs" across a multitude of industries, technical and non-technical professionals continue to graduate from universities and workforce programs without a foundational understanding of sustainability or the emerging energy technologies that will drive future production. Meanwhile, workforce surveys suggest that an increasing number of employers are hiring individuals for "green-enhanced" positions who possess knowledge of renewable energy systems and sustainable design within the context of a broader (or "traditional") field of expertise, such as engineering or construction management.

Because they uphold a dual mission of providing workforce education and instruction for university transfer, community colleges and similar "open access" public institutions serve as a vital higher education crossroads for more than 40% of college students nationwide (AACC 2019), and are especially important for the advancement of non-traditional and under-served student populations. This transitional nature allows community and state colleges to be uniquely impactful for the promulgation of core sustainability concepts and renewable energy literacy.

Certificate & Curriculum Development

With the EMERGE project ("Establishing a Means for Effective Renewable & Green Energy"), Seminole State College of Florida has adopted a unique multidisciplinary approach to sustainability education, which features course options both for technical training in alternative energy and green construction, as well as enhanced liberal arts curricula for project-based and applied sustainability.

Tailored to the needs of first- and second-year undergraduates, the Sustainability Certificate developed during this project can be adapted to complement a variety of two- and four-year (A.S. & B.S.) degrees offered through the institution?s School of Engineering, Design & Construction or to pair with the "pre-major" studies of A.A. students who plan to transfer to a university following their sophomore years.

Students pursuing this certificate must complete a progression of six classes, which includes a survey course in alternative energy sources; a class in solar power and/or electrical concepts; and either an introduction to sustainability issues or a primer on energy and environmental policy. Technical and non-technical electives available to students include sustainability courses in business, interior design, energy analysis, green building and tiny house living. The certificate culminates in a student-designed "project in sustainability," which provides an opportunity for participants to receive instructor guidance on the planning and implementation of a project uniquely attuned to their own educational or career interests.

The hands-on project experiences promoted by this multi-faceted curriculum can serve as a resume differentiator for students entering the green workforce--whether their formal academic training lies in engineering technology, drafting and design, construction, business management or beyond.

As supplement to the creation of the formal Sustainability Certificate program, the EMERGE project has also aimed to increase the exposure of STEM and non-STEM majors alike to sustainability content within diverse academic contexts. Program initiatives have increased experiential learning, sponsored field trips, guest lectures and development opportunities for students and faculty. Disciplines impacted by project activities range widely from biology and chemistry, where lab exercises have been revised to minimize waste and reduce the use of hazardous chemicals, on to fine arts and theatre, where students of stagecraft have been introduced to the principles of green theatre and sustainable design.

By pursuing a flexible curricular approach to sustainability education aimed at a broad base of students within the community college setting, the EMERGE project has substantially increased enrollment in sustainability courses and expanded student knowledge of sustainability and renewable concepts. These efforts will help to produce a better-informed global citizenry and a workforce literate in the key concepts of sustainability, who have the necessary vocabulary to work, plan, and adapt to our changing world.
